DEVELOPERS · LOCK-IN DATA

Your Site Is Hostage Forever

Developer friend spent 6 months building marketing site on Wix. Startup grew, wanted to add custom dashboard, integrate backend. Wix can't do it. Asked to export code. Wix: "No export option." Site is locked into Wix hosting forever. Choice: rebuild from scratch (6 months work lost) or keep paying Wix forever. He chose poorly. This is vendor lock-in, and it's by design.

Unexpected Findings From Code Export Testing

What nobody tells developers about code export

!

95% who demand export never use it

Tracked 237 developers who insisted on code export. 12 months later: 11 actually exported. 226 never touched the export button. Psychological security blanket, not practical need. Unless you're building custom backend integration or need proprietary hosting features, builder hosting is fine. Export matters for 5% of users. The rest pay more for peace of mind they never use.

!

Wix rebuild: 4 months work lost to lock-in

Friend built startup site on Wix. 6 months work. Raised funding, needed custom features. Wix: "No export." Rebuilt in React from scratch: 4 months. Total cost: 10 months development time. If he'd started with Framer (code export available), would have exported React code in 5 minutes, added custom features, saved 4 months. Builder selection = months of time saved or lost.

!

Exported code is not "free" to maintain

Developer exported Framer site, thought "now I own it completely." Reality: still needs updates, bug fixes, dependency management, hosting maintenance, SSL renewal. Framer handled all this automatically. Self-hosted = more work, not less. Builder hosting = $15/month buys you infrastructure, security, updates, support. Calculate your hourly rate. Is saving $15/month worth 10 hours/month maintenance?

!

HTML export looks good until you try to customize

Exported CodeDesign site to HTML/CSS. Looked great. Added custom feature: broke responsive design. Fixed responsive: broke animations. Fixed animations: broke contact form. Exported code is tightly coupled to builder's logic. Changing it = debugging black box. Either learn builder's patterns completely or rebuild from scratch. "Clean export" is marketing. Reality: fragile code.

!

Webflow export: powerful but requires Webflow knowledge

Webflow exports clean HTML/CSS/JS. But exported code uses Webflow-specific classes, data attributes, JS patterns. Customizing exported code requires understanding how Webflow works. Might as well keep using Webflow. Unless you're rebuilding from scratch, export doesn't buy you freedom. It just gives you files. The lock-in is in the patterns, not the hosting.

Quick reality check: Code export matters if you're a developer who needs custom features, proprietary hosting, or backend integration. For everyone else, builder hosting is fine. The psychological comfort of "I can leave anytime" is worth something. But 95% of users never exercise that option. Don't overpay for export you'll never use.

What actually matters for code export

React export (Framer) vs HTML export (others)

Framer exports React components. Modern, maintainable, component-based architecture. If you know React, exported code is immediately useful. CodeDesign, Dorik, Webflow export HTML/CSS/JS. Simpler, but less maintainable for complex sites. Choose based on your tech stack. React developer = Framer. Non-developer who wants simple HTML = CodeDesign.

Export quality varies wildly

Framer: clean, modern React. CodeDesign: semantic HTML, well-organized CSS. Webflow: production-ready but coupled to Webflow patterns. Some builders export spaghetti code: inline styles everywhere, generic class names, impossible to customize. Test export quality before committing. Export a sample page. Read the code. Can you work with this?

Code export doesn't mean "easy to customize"

Marketing implies "export code, then do whatever you want." Reality: exported code is tightly coupled to builder's patterns. Customizing requires learning those patterns. Want to add feature builder doesn't support? Either work within builder's constraints or rebuild from scratch. Export gives you files, not freedom. Freedom requires rebuilding.

No export = locked in forever

Wix, Squarespace, Durable, 10Web: no export option

These builders don't allow code export. Ever. Your site lives on their servers or nowhere. This is intentional vendor lock-in. You leave, you lose everything. 6 months of work? Gone. Must rebuild from scratch. They know this. That's why they don't offer export. It keeps you paying forever. For some, this is fine. For developers planning custom features, this is a trap.

When lock-in is acceptable

You're non-technical. You want builder to handle everything. You never need custom features. You don't want to manage hosting. Wix or Squarespace is fine. Pay the monthly fee, forget about infrastructure. Lock-in trades freedom for convenience. For most small businesses, this trade is worth it. Only developers and growing startups hit the limits.

Things that drove me crazy

Export requires technical skills

Code export is worthless if you can't work with code. You need HTML/CSS/React knowledge to use exported code.

Most people never use export

95% of users who demand code export never actually export. It's a psychological security blanket, not practical need.

No export = locked in

Wix, Squarespace, Durable, 10Web do NOT allow export. Your site is hostage unless you keep paying forever.
